pages.body:
Here is what I did for my headless Ubuntu 19.04 server.

# Install TOR to enable functionality with zeronet.  [Source](https://www.linuxuprising.com/2018/10/how-to-install-and-use-tor-as-proxy-in.html)

 - Start by installing apt-transport-https, needed in order to use https repositories, and curl, to download the repository key:

`sudo apt install apt-transport-https curl`

 - And then add the Tor repository (and its key) in Ubuntu using these commands:

`sudo -i`

`echo "deb https://deb.torproject.org/torproject.org/ $(lsb_release -cs) main" > /etc/apt/sources.list.d/tor.list`

`curl https://deb.torproject.org/torproject.org/A3C4F0F979CAA22CDBA8F512EE8CBC9E886DDD89.asc | gpg --import`

`gpg --export A3C4F0F979CAA22CDBA8F512EE8CBC9E886DDD89 | apt-key add -`

`apt update`

`exit`

For Linux Mint, replace `$(lsb_release -cs)` in the first command with the Ubuntu version codename your Linux Mint version is based on. For Linux Mint 19 (and 19.x), use bionic, while for Linux Mint 18.x use xenial.

 - Now you can install Tor, tor-geoipdb (to be able to use country specific exit nodes), torsocks (a library to easily torify applications) and deb.torproject.org-keyring (a package that makes sure you have the latest repository signing key):

`sudo apt install tor tor-geoipdb torsocks deb.torproject.org-keyring`

# Prepare TOR to work with Zeronet,  [Source](https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq/#how-to-use-zeronet-with-tor)

 - Open up your /etc/tor/torrc file with

`sudo nano /etc/tor/torrc`

 - Remove the # character from lines `ControlPort 9051` and `CookieAuthentication 1` (line ~57)
    
 - Restart tor, then add permission for yourself to read the auth cookie. With Debian Linux, 

`sudo usermod -a -G debian-tor [yourlinuxuser]`

(be sure to replace [yourlinuxuser] appropratly)
 - Logout/Login with your user to apply group changes

Tip: You can verify if your Tor setup is running correctly using
`echo 'PROTOCOLINFO' | nc 127.0.0.1 9051`

# Install Zeronet for Debian Linux,  [Source](https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/using_zeronet/installing/#manual-install-for-debian-linux)

`sudo apt-get update`

`sudo apt-get install msgpack-python python-gevent`

`wget https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/archive/master.tar.gz`

`tar xvpfz master.tar.gz`
	
# Enable the Bootstrapper and UIPassword plugins and launch Zeronet

`cd ZeroNet-master`

`cd plugins`

`mv disabled-UiPassword UiPassword`

`mv disabled-Bootstrapper Bootstrapper`

`cd ..`

`nohup ./zeronet.py --ui_ip "*" --ui_port 80 --ui_password P@$$w0rd`

 - Now you can close your terminal and open your browser to the ip address of your server to see the WebUI.

Notes: 
(ui_ip tells the client that any IP can access the servers UI)
(ui_port) being set to 80 is the default port for your browser, you can change it but then you will need to specify the port with the addres such as `http://127.0.0.1:43110` with 43110 being the identified port for the WebUI
(ui_password) this is the password used for your WebUI

The Copyright Wall-Of-Shame === Reminder for all that 9 out of 10 times, the people who make a shitstorm about morality and ethics are the same people who don't abide by them and actually do worse things. This number increases to 10/10 with anti-pirate collectives as they have been observed and proven in these past few years of: 01. UK-based music company De Wolfe Music using the content monetization company AdRev Publishing to [issue a takedown claim of ownership against a piece of music enclosed within a video](https://torrentfreak.com/kenyan-govt-protests-as-national-anthem-hit-with-youtube-copyright-complaint-190206/) uploaded by 2nacheki that contained a music work titled ‘Ee Mungu Nguvu Yetu’ (‘O God, of all Creation’)) to be its property, although it was written by the Kenyan Anthem Commission in 1963 to serve as the state anthem. 01. UMG/Deutsche Grammophon insisting on the [validity of their Youtube takedown claim relating to {Sinfonie Nr. 8 von F. Schubert und Sinfonie Nr. 5 von L.v. Beethoven, even though the protection date is explicitly stated as 1961 on the record itself](http://cc0.oer-musik.de/Home/EnAbout), with YouTube being not available to either solve or review the contested claim by Deutsche Grammophon/UMG. 01. Three anti-piracy lawyers who were employed by the anti-piracy group Antipiratgruppen, [being caught swindling almost $16 million dollars from the MPAA and other Rights holders](https://torrentfreak.com/anti-piracy-lawyers-sentenced-to-years-in-prison-for-defrauding-copyright-holders-180612/), in which the trio was ordered to serve prison sentencing for two to five years but are free to practice law upon release. 01. Sweden ISP Bahnhof calling into question [the validity of Sweedish judges who have ruled favorable on copyright cases](https://torrentfreak.com/isp-questions-impartiality-of-judges-in-copyright-troll-cases-180602/) while possessing a conflict of interests by maintaining their corporate relations. 01. Adobe [failing to pay licensing fees on the sales of Adobe products that contained Dolby technology](https://torrentfreak.com/dolby-labs-sues-adobe-for-copyright-infringement-180314/) by refusing to provide the agreed upon sales audits for multiple years over]. Demonstrating that the largest and most wealthiest of copyright enthusiasts will also happily ignore copyright conditions when it suits their own agenda. 01. Copyright enthusiast David Lowery casting criticism at professor Michael Geist over the importance of copyright acknowledgement all [while failing to obtain the proper license on an image shared in the Blog post](https://torrentfreak.com/when-a-pro-copyright-rant-goes-wrong-180225/). 01. FlightSimLabs [planting SecurityXploded.Com's ChromePasswordDump v5.5 to successfully capture the stored Google Chrome passwords](https://torrentfreak.com/flight-sim-company-embeds-malware-to-steal-pirates-passwords-180219/) of users who are allegedly using product keys that are found on file-sharing sites. 01. The company behind the 2015 drama film Fathers & Daughters [having their copyright infringement case being dismissed](https://torrentfreak.com/judge-tells-movie-company-that-it-cant-sue-alleged-bittorrent-pirate-180118/) due to the company's exclusive rights to the movie being sold to a company called Vertical Entertainment who were not part of the lawsuit. [{orig}](https://fightcopyrighttrolls.com/2018/01/17/federal-judge-fathers-and-daughters-nevada-llc-has-no-standing-to-sue-for-bittorent-copyright-infringement/) 01. Youtube allowing [multiple RIAA members to claim & monetize an uploaded video that contained nothing but white static noise.](https://torrentfreak.com/musicians-white-noise-youtube-video-hit-with-copyright-complaints-180105/) Illustrating that copyright is fundamentally broken and is only suitable to benefit a very select privileged few. 01. Music copyright advocates using the DMCA and domain seizures to cause irreparable harm to mash up sites like [Sowndhaus](https://torrentfreak.com/could-a-single-copyright-complaint-kill-your-domain-171203/) & [Spinrilla](https://torrentfreak.com/riaa-labels-sue-hip-hop-mixtape-download-site-spinrilla-170206/) by taking action of litigation without ever notifying the website owners of the [claim of infringement](https://torrentfreak.com/piracy-riaa-labels-asked-us-to-promote-their-music-spinrilla-says-170316/). 01. Epic Games' [taking aggressive judicial action against a 14 year old "Fortnite" cheater](https://torrentfreak.com/mom-defends-14-year-old-fortnite-cheater-in-court-171125/) over the usage of an online game cheat and multiple free accounts registered with fake email addresses. Demonstrating that copyright litigation is often the action of choice with little consideration of who may be targeted. 01. ABC, AOL, CBS Broadcasting, NBCUniversal, NPR, Time, Viacom, Warner Bros, Yahoo and Ziff Davi [settling with numerous photographers due to infringing use of their photographs](https://torrentfreak.com/pirating-mainstream-media-outlets-haunted-by-photographers-in-court-171028/) found throughout their News & Blog articles. In which CBS later [counter sue due to a Gunsmoke screen shot being posted on social media](https://torrentfreak.com/cbs-sues-man-for-posting-image-of-a-59-year-tv-show-on-social-media-171030/) in an attempt to reduce their damage settlement. Demonstrating that not even those who actively litigate copyright law don't bare any respect for it. 01. New Zealand's ruling National Party being [forced to pay $600k for infringing the copyrights of Eminem's track "Lose Yourself" due to using a derivative song with a similar melody for their campaign ad](https://torrentfreak.com/lose-yourself-national-party-guilty-of-eminem-copyright-infringement-171025/) demonstrating that even when obtaining proper licenses will not prevent a copyright related lawsuit. 01. Four officials of the Russian site-blocking body [Rozcomnadzor, {including spokesman, top lawyer, and Anastasiya Zvyagintseva} being charged with fraud](https://torrentfreak.com/russian-site-blocking-chiefs-under-investigation-for-fraud-171024/) and stand accused of having 'employed' ghost staff whose salaries were actually paid to existing employees, on top of their own money all while being allowed to block 4,000 sites on copyright grounds with an additional 41,000 innocent websites blocked as collateral damage demonstrating that copyright law often leaves a trail of harm rather than any potential good. 01. Game developer [Atlus targeting the Patreon page of the RPCS3 {Playstation 3} emulator with a DMCA takedown notice](https://torrentfreak.com/of-course-atlus-hit-rpcs3s-patreon-page-over-persona-5-170927/) due to a comment which stated that Atlus' game title Persona 5 will be compatible with the RPCS3 emulator, which resulted in an intimidation tactic that persuaded the RPCS3 development team to remove all occurrences of the compatibility reference from their Patreon and other pages while Atlus admits that the RPCS3 team has done nothing wrong nor infringed on any of their rights. Illustrating that abusive claims of copyright infringement are often made without hesitance. 01. Sega attempting to trick Steam users [by sneaking Denuvo into their Sonic Mania release by not specifying the third party DRM EULA on the store front page](https://www.gamespot.com/articles/sonic-mania-pcs-drm-angers-players-sega-adds-offli/1100-6452993/) while the game was on pre-order and also handing out [a 'free' emulated Sonic the Hedgehog Sega Genesis/Mega Drive game](https://www.gamespot.com/articles/four-days-before-release-sonic-mania-pc-delayed-bu/1100-6452474/) to hinder the [issuance of refunds](http://store.steampowered.com/steam_refunds). 01. Media giant [ABS-CBN using the judiciary favor of a Florida Federal court to establish a $1.8 million dollar settlement from the operator of KissAsian,ch who is likely not a US citizen.](https://torrentfreak.com/florida-court-orders-pirate-site-kissasian-to-pay-1-8m-in-damages-170825/) Allowing much needed US resources to be devoted to foreign parties regarding their foreign affairs. 01. The [RIAA refusing to give accreditation to their musical artists and piece composers](https://torrentfreak.com/riaa-says-artists-dont-need-moral-rights-artists-disagree-170521/) with the refusal reason of ['it would be "complex" to always attribute writers for their work".](https://torrentfreak.com/artists-protest-riaa-for-trampling-on-their-moral-rights-170817/) 01. Flava Works [attempting to extort huge sums of cash {$97,000 – $525,000} from WE,tv's President & General Manager Marc Juris with threats of exposing his sexual preference to the public](https://torrentfreak.com/public-figure-threatened-with-exposure-over-gay-piracy-fine-170817/) in the event of failure to pay. Which, once again, illustrating that copyright enforcers are often worse than the most hardened of criminals. 01. The Anti-Ad-Blocking company [Admiral submitting a DMCA removal notice to the EasyList {ad-blocker definition} Github repository with the goal of having the Ad Server URl entry 'functionalclam.com^$third-party' removed from the list.](https://torrentfreak.com/dmca-used-to-remove-ad-server-url-from-easylist-ad-blocklist-170811/) Creating a slippery slope for future removals. 01. Copyright extortionists manipulation of the courts, led by Kerry Culpeppe and using intimidation tactics to accuse a [72 year old man](https://torrentfreak.com/72-year-old-man-accused-of-pirating-over-a-thousand-torrents-170810/), a [Texan woman](https://torrentfreak.com/copyright-troll-claims-texan-woman-downloaded-over-54000-torrents-170713/), and [others](https://torrentfreak.com/86-year-old-grandma-accused-of-pirating-a-zombie-game-161031/) of mass infringement. 01. Telecom giant's Dish Network, Bell Canada, TVA, Videotron, and Rogers abuse of the judicial system with the goals of [shutting down TVAddons and intimidating Canadian resident Adam Lackman by allowing private agencies to seize control of the platform and equipment](https://torrentfreak.com/tvaddons-returns-ugly-war-canadian-telcos-kodi-addons-170801/) without any chance of legal representation or any real sense of justice or due process for the site operator. {Those who wish to show support can do so [[here](https://www.generosity.com/community-fundraising/tvaddons-legal-defense-fund)]} 01. The [RIAA making attempts to bring litigation against Cloudflare concerning numerous MP3Skull domains in an attempt to illustrate to the courts that Cloudflare is facilitating the activities of controversial sites](https://torrentfreak.com/cloudflare-asks-court-to-vacate-moot-pirate-site-blocking-order-170724/), regardless that the domains were owned by Sony Music Entertainment, who is an RIAA member. 01. [The Daily Mail willfully infringing copyrights and using unlicensed viral YouTube videos to promote their articles](https://torrentfreak.com/daily-mail-sued-for-pirating-dozens-of-viral-videos-170711/). # Welcome to ZeroNet

[[ZeroWiki]] is a wiki platform for [[ZeroNet]], the distributed web network based on [[Bittorrent]], [[Bitcoin]] and [[Tor]]. 

[[ZeroWiki]] is public, [[cloning|clonable]]. Wikis can be used for taking notes, storing snippets, sharing knowledge by creating [[FAQ]]s and documentations, keeping track of your goals, or as simple to-do lists. See the [[help|help page]] for a more in-depth view of how it works. ZeroWiki solves the huge problem which wikipedia has, namely, that wikipedia is controlled by deletion-trolls and brainwashed scum admins.

# Wiki help

To help you navigate this wiki there is a Home and Index button in every page. Feel free to click any link you see in the texts too, they will take you to magic places.

Blue links will take you to existing pages which already have content and intersting things for you to read. On the other hand, red links will lead you to pages that do not exist yet, you will be able to add content and write some spells to create them.

Most of the pages in this wiki are editable too! just look for the Edit button if you feel the urge to modify what you are reading. This is a collaborative tool for shared knowledge, improve the contents, show your kung-fu, and the community will be grateful forever with dances and songs to remember your feat.

## Text editing

This wiki uses  [[markdown|Markdown]] to format the texts, use it to add titles, to make your text bold or to add links to external resources.

To create links to new or existing pages in this wiki, just use double square brackets around words. The wiki will auto-magically convert it to wiki-links. It will also detect if the page already exists and use the corresponding color to display the link.

### Final words

No, just kidding. Now go and enjoy the wiki!

# MarkDown Cheatsheet ## Headers ``` # H1 ## H2 ### H3 #### H4 ##### H5 ###### H6 Alternatively, for H1 and H2, an underline-ish style: Alt-H1 ====== Alt-H2 ------ ``` # H1 ## H2 ### H3 #### H4 ##### H5 ###### H6 Alternatively, for H1 and H2, an underline-ish style: Alt-H1 ====== Alt-H2 ------ ## Emphasis ``` Emphasis, aka italics, with *asterisks* or _underscores_. Strong emphasis, aka bold, with **asterisks** or __underscores__. Combined emphasis with **asterisks and _underscores_**. Strikethrough uses two tildes. ~~Scratch this.~~ ``` Emphasis, aka italics, with *asterisks* or _underscores_. Strong emphasis, aka bold, with **asterisks** or __underscores__. Combined emphasis with **asterisks and _underscores_**. Strikethrough uses two tildes. ~~Scratch this.~~ ## Lists (In this example, leading and trailing spaces are shown with with dots: ⋅) ``` 1. First ordered list item 2. Another item ⋅⋅* Unordered sub-list. 1. Actual numbers don't matter, just that it's a number ⋅⋅1. Ordered sub-list 4. And another item. ⋅⋅⋅You can have properly indented paragraphs within list items. Notice the blank line above, and the leading spaces (at least one, but we'll use three here to also align the raw Markdown). ⋅⋅⋅To have a line break without a paragraph, you will need to use two trailing spaces.⋅⋅ ⋅⋅⋅Note that this line is separate, but within the same paragraph.⋅⋅ ⋅⋅⋅(This is contrary to the typical GFM line break behaviour, where trailing spaces are not required.) ``` * Unordered list can use asterisks - Or minuses + Or pluses 1. First ordered list item 2. Another item ⋅⋅* Unordered sub-list. 1. Actual numbers don't matter, just that it's a number ⋅⋅1. Ordered sub-list 4. And another item. ⋅⋅⋅You can have properly indented paragraphs within list items. Notice the blank line above, and the leading spaces (at least one, but we'll use three here to also align the raw Markdown). ⋅⋅⋅To have a line break without a paragraph, you will need to use two trailing spaces.⋅⋅ ⋅⋅⋅Note that this line is separate, but within the same paragraph.⋅⋅ ⋅⋅⋅(This is contrary to the typical GFM line break behaviour, where trailing spaces are not required.) * Unordered list can use asterisks - Or minuses + Or pluses ## Links There are two ways to create links. ``` [I'm an inline-style link](https://www.google.com) [I'm an inline-style link with title](https://www.google.com "Google's Homepage") [I'm a reference-style link][Arbitrary case-insensitive reference text] [I'm a relative reference to a repository file](../blob/master/LICENSE) [You can use numbers for reference-style link definitions][1] Or leave it empty and use the [link text itself]. URLs and URLs in angle brackets will automatically get turned into links. http://www.example.com or and sometimes example.com (but not on Github, for example). Some text to show that the reference links can follow later. [arbitrary case-insensitive reference text]: https://www.mozilla.org [1]: http://slashdot.org [link text itself]: http://www.reddit.com ``` [I'm an inline-style link](https://www.google.com) [I'm an inline-style link with title](https://www.google.com "Google's Homepage") [I'm a reference-style link][Arbitrary case-insensitive reference text] [I'm a relative reference to a repository file](../blob/master/LICENSE) [You can use numbers for reference-style link definitions][1] Or leave it empty and use the [link text itself]. URLs and URLs in angle brackets will automatically get turned into links. http://www.example.com or and sometimes example.com (but not on Github, for example). Some text to show that the reference links can follow later. [arbitrary case-insensitive reference text]: https://www.mozilla.org [1]: http://slashdot.org [link text itself]: http://www.reddit.com ## Images ``` Here's our logo (hover to see the title text): Inline-style: ![alt text](https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/raw/master/src/common/images/icon48.png "Logo Title Text 1") Reference-style: ![alt text][logo] [logo]: https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/raw/master/src/common/images/icon48.png "Logo Title Text 2" ``` Here's our logo (hover to see the title text): Inline-style: ![alt text](https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/raw/master/src/common/images/icon48.png "Logo Title Text 1") Reference-style: ![alt text][logo] [logo]: https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/raw/master/src/common/images/icon48.png "Logo Title Text 2" ## Code and Syntax Highlighting Code blocks are part of the Markdown spec, but syntax highlighting isn't. However, many renderers -- like Github's and Markdown Here -- support syntax highlighting. Which languages are supported and how those language names should be written will vary from renderer to renderer. Markdown Here supports highlighting for dozens of languages (and not-really-languages, like diffs and HTTP headers); to see the complete list, and how to write the language names, see the highlight.js demo page. ``` Inline `code` has `back-ticks around` it. ``` Inline `code` has `back-ticks around` it. Blocks of code are either fenced by lines with three back-ticks ```, or are indented with four spaces. I recommend only using the fenced code blocks -- they're easier and only they support syntax highlighting. ``` ```javascript var s = "JavaScript syntax highlighting"; alert(s); ``` ```python s = "Python syntax highlighting" print s ``` ``` No language indicated, so no syntax highlighting. But let's throw in a tag. ``` ``` ```javascript var s = "JavaScript syntax highlighting"; alert(s); ``` ```python s = "Python syntax highlighting" print s ``` ``` No language indicated, so no syntax highlighting. But let's throw in a tag. ``` ## Tables Tables aren't part of the core Markdown spec, but they are part of GFM and Markdown Here supports them. They are an easy way of adding tables to your email -- a task that would otherwise require copy-pasting from another application. ``` Colons can be used to align columns. | Tables | Are | Cool | | ------------- |:-------------:| -----:| | col 3 is | right-aligned | $1600 | | col 2 is | centered | $12 | | zebra stripes | are neat | $1 | There must be at least 3 dashes separating each header cell. The outer pipes (|) are optional, and you don't need to make the raw Markdown line up prettily. You can also use inline Markdown. Markdown | Less | Pretty --- | --- | --- *Still* | `renders` | **nicely** 1 | 2 | 3 ``` Colons can be used to align columns. | Tables | Are | Cool | | ------------- |:-------------:| -----:| | col 3 is | right-aligned | $1600 | | col 2 is | centered | $12 | | zebra stripes | are neat | $1 | There must be at least 3 dashes separating each header cell. Markdown | Less | Pretty --- | --- | --- *Still* | `renders` | **nicely** 1 | 2 | 3 ## Blockquotes ``` > Blockquotes are very handy in email to emulate reply text. > This line is part of the same quote. Quote break. > This is a very long line that will still be quoted properly when it wraps. Oh boy let's keep writing to make sure this is long enough to actually wrap for everyone. Oh, you can *put* **Markdown** into a blockquote. ``` > Blockquotes are very handy in email to emulate reply text. > This line is part of the same quote. Quote break. > This is a very long line that will still be quoted properly when it wraps. Oh boy let's keep writing to make sure this is long enough to actually wrap for everyone. Oh, you can *put* **Markdown** into a blockquote. ## Inline HTML You can also use raw HTML in your Markdown, and it'll mostly work pretty well. ```
Definition list
Is something people use sometimes.
Markdown in HTML
Does *not* work **very** well. Use HTML tags.

## Horizontal Rule ``` Three or more... --- Hyphens *** Asterisks ___ ``` Three or more... --- Hyphens *** Asterisks ___ Underscores ## Line Breaks My basic recommendation for learning how line breaks work is to experiment and discover -- hit once (i.e., insert one newline), then hit it twice (i.e., insert two newlines), see what happens. You'll soon learn to get what you want. "Markdown Toggle" is your friend. Here are some things to try out: ``` Here's a line for us to start with. This line is separated from the one above by two newlines, so it will be a *separate paragraph*. This line is also a separate paragraph, but... This line is only separated by a single newline, so it's a separate line in the *same paragraph*. ``` Here's a line for us to start with. This line is separated from the one above by two newlines, so it will be a *separate paragraph*. This line is also a separate paragraph, but... This line is only separated by a single newline, so it's a separate line in the *same paragraph*. ## External links * [Markdown Guide](https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/wiki/Markdown-Cheatsheet#headers) * [official website](http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/) * [wikipedia entry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markdown)

[arbitrary case-insensitive reference text]: https://www.mozilla.org [1]: http://slashdot.org [link text itself]: http://www.reddit.com ``` [I'm an inline-style link](https://www.google.com) [I'm an inline-style link with title](https://www.google.com "Google's Homepage") [I'm a reference-style link][Arbitrary case-insensitive reference text] [I'm a relative reference to a repository file](../blob/master/LICENSE) [You can use numbers for reference-style link definitions][1] Or leave it empty and use the [link text itself]. [arbitrary case-insensitive reference text]: https://www.mozilla.org [1]: http://slashdot.org [link text itself]: http://www.reddit.com ##Images ``` Here's our logo (hover to see the title text): Inline-style: ![alt text](https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/raw/master/src/common/images/icon48.png "Logo Title Text 1") Reference-style: ![alt text][logo] [logo]: https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/raw/master/src/common/images/icon48.png "Logo Title Text 2" ``` Here's our logo (hover to see the title text): Inline-style: ![alt text](https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/raw/master/src/common/images/icon48.png "Logo Title Text 1") Reference-style: ![alt text][logo] [logo]: https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/raw/master/src/common/images/icon48.png "Logo Title Text 2" ##Code and Syntax Highlighting Code blocks are part of the Markdown spec, but syntax highlighting isn't. However, many renderers -- like Github's and Markdown Here -- support syntax highlighting. Which languages are supported and how those language names should be written will vary from renderer to renderer. Markdown Here supports highlighting for dozens of languages (and not-really-languages, like diffs and HTTP headers); to see the complete list, and how to write the language names, see the highlight.js demo page. ``` Inline `code` has `back-ticks around` it. ``` Inline `code` has `back-ticks around` it. Blocks of code are either fenced by lines with three back-ticks ```, or are indented with four spaces. I recommend only using the fenced code blocks -- they're easier and only they support syntax highlighting. ``` ```javascript var s = "JavaScript syntax highlighting"; alert(s); ``` ```python s = "Python syntax highlighting" print s ``` ``` No language indicated, so no syntax highlighting. But let's throw in a tag. ``` ``` ```javascript var s = "JavaScript syntax highlighting"; alert(s); ``` ```python s = "Python syntax highlighting" print s ``` ``` No language indicated, so no syntax highlighting. But let's throw in a tag. ``` ## External links * [official website](http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/) * [wikipedia entry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markdown)

# H1

# MarkDown

MarkDown is a lightweight markup language for formatting plain text in an easy and intuitive way. It's looks similar to ‘formatting’ conventions which were already in use for plain text e-mail and chat.

## Example

    Heading (1st level)
    ===
    
    Sub-heading (2nd level)
    ---
    
    ### Sub-sub-heading (3rd level, alternative notation)
    
    Just some text purely 
    for demonstration purpose.
    
    We can also make text
    /italic/, **bold** or ___both___
    
    > It actually depends amount of used symbols
    but it does not matter if it is /, * or _
    
    we can also have lists
    * and `code`
    + [links](/0list.bit) [📎](/186THqMWuptrZxq1rxzpguAivK3Bs6z84o)
    - as well as horizontal rules
    
    ---
    1. numbered
    2. lists work
    3. as well

### How can I let people access my site without installing ZeroNet ?
  * You can use a proxy, see [[proxies]] for a list of proxies.  
  
### Is there a way to block any SPAM that I see from a particular Zeronet user?
Yes, you are able to issue a global mute on any user that has a registered ID. This will prevent any material that user(s) may post on most zites available. You can issue a global mute on a user by following these steps:  
  1. Visit zeroid.bit or the Identification service that user is registered with
  2. Click the button link that reads: "Search in user database..."
  3. In the text box that appears, type in the users display name that you wish to mute. For example if the user's name was xyz@zeroid.bit, one would enter xyz
  4. If a green 'found' message is displayed, click the yellow 'Mute User' button.
  5. In the top right corder of your screen a Confirmation dialog will appear. Click 'Mute' to enable the global mute. Otherwise click the small [x] to the right of the Mute button to cancel the mute request and dismiss the dialog.
  6. The user has been successfully muted. You can now close the ZeroID page and reload any pages to remove undesired posts or media.
  
### How do you unmute a user after muting them through zeroid?
  * From the main menu on the ZeroHello (main page). Click on  Manage muted users.  
  
### When trying to setup a zeronet proxy, what can help remedy the 'Invalid host' error when attempting to access the proxy outside of the local network?
 
  * If you are using a domain launch zeronet with this command:  
 ``` python zeronet.py --ui_port 80 --ui_host www.mydomain.com mydomain.com 127.0.0.1 --ui_ip '*'  ``` 

  * If you aren't using a domain replace (xx) with your public IP:  
 ``` python zeronet.py --ui_port 80 --ui_host xx.xx.xx.xx 127.0.0.1 --ui_ip '*' ```

[[ZeroWiki]] is a wiki platform for [[ZeroNet]], the distributed web network based on [[Bittorrent]], [[Bitcoin]] and [[Tor]]. 

[[ZeroWiki]] is public, [[cloning|clonable]]. Wikis can be used for taking notes, storing snippets, sharing knowledge by creating [[FAQ]]s and documentations, keeping track of your goals, or as simple to-do lists. See the [[help|help page]] for a more in-depth view of how it works.

  * If you are using a domain launch zeronet with this command:  
 ``` python zeronet.py --ui_port 80 --ui_host www.mydomain.com mydomain.com 127.0.0.1 --ui_ip '*'  ``` 

  * If you aren't using a domain replace (xx) with your public IP:  
 ``` python zeronet.py --ui_port 80 --ui_host xx.xx.xx.xx 127.0.0.1 --ui_ip '*' ``` 

### Is there any way I can see who is connected to me and how many people I am connected to?
  * Yes, there is a dedicated page for viewing this information which is available at http://127.0.0.1:43110/Stats

### Is there a way to block any SPAM that I see from a particular Zeronet user?
Yes, you are able to issue a global mute on any user that has a registered ID. This will prevent any material that user(s) may post on most zites available. You can issue a global mute on a user by following these steps:  
  1. Visit zeroid.bit or the Identification service that user is registered with
  2. Click the button link that reads: "Search in user database..."
  3. In the text box that appears, type in the users display name that you wish to mute. For example if the user's name was xyz@zeroid.bit, one would enter xyz
  4. If a green 'found' message is displayed, click the yellow 'Mute User' button.
  5. In the top right corder of your screen a Confirmation dialog will appear. Click 'Mute' to enable the global mute. Otherwise click the small [x] to the right of the Mute button to cancel the mute request and dismiss the dialog.
  6. The user has been successfully muted. You can now close the ZeroID page and reload any pages to remove undesired posts or media.

# Proxies

A proxy is a website that you can reach using any web-capable device that runs a multi-user [[ZeroNet]] instance. *[Learn how to host one](/kindlyfire.bit/?Post:9:Running+a+ZeroProxy)*. You can also install [[AWS Shadow Socks]].

There also is a website dedicated to listing proxies: [zeroproxies.bit](/zeroproxies.bit), but it is outdated.
